717098f.text:
Broadway, between Vesey and Fulton Street, from the Church yard of Saint Pauls, before many old trees were
cut down.
E.L.Henry
MAY PE REPRODUCED  1870.

717092f.text:
Broadway, north from no. 200.
"Rare view showing the building of the New York
Post Office."'
The fourth story of the Post Office was completed Oct. 1, 1873 (Stokes, Iconography of Manhattan Island, v.6 p.542) This view must date from early 1873.

Neg.#2176

717123f-a.text:
212, 214 and 218 Broadway, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Fulton Street (right) showing the Knox (later,,the United) Building and the National Park Bank. On the left appears a portion of the United States Post Office, of which, the Park Row side is seen. The building bearing the advertising sign, No. 218 was the site of Barnums Museum and is today (1937) a part of the 25-story St. Paul Building site; the other
structures remaining the same.
1898.
Brown Brothers.

717101f-a.text:
Broadway and Church Street, between Fulton and Vesey Streets, showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel.
M.B.R.  1900.

717104f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Fulton to Vesey Streets. Two eastward views of St. Pauls Chapel and graveyard. Broadway is to the rear of same and the additional structures appearing are there upon. Note the old Astor House at the right margin.
About 1900
Views 1,2
Thomas W. Kennedy photo
Thru Beecher Ogden

717104f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, from Fulton to Vesey Streets. Two eastward views of St. Pauls Chapel and graveyard. Broadway is to the rear of same and the additional structures appearing are there upon. Note the old Astor House at the right margin.
About 1900
Views 1,2
Thomas W. Kennedy photo
Thru Beecher Ogden

717099f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including Fulton Street, showing possibly a curb trading group at the S.E. corner of same. On the left appears St. Pauls P.E. Chapel, the Astor House, The Postal Telegraph and Cable Building and the turret of the Home Life Insurance Co. Building. On the opposite side one sees a portion of City Hall Park and the United States Post Office; the latter obscured by the columns of the National Park Bank Building. Under ground, at this point the I.R.T. Subway is
under construction.
August 25, 1903.
Cormdoiidated Edieon Co.
NRcq wt 99t;

717106f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Fulton Street. St. Pauls' P.E. Chapel is on the left and occupies the frontage from Fulton to Vesey Streets. Under demolition in the next block is half of the old Astor House. This is to be improved with a 7-story structure. Subsequently the remainder will be razed for the site of the 44-story Transportation Building. The magnificent 55-storied Woolworth Building is just north of the latter location. The pyramidal topped structure beyond is the Postal Telegraph and Cable Building.
1913-4
Thru New York Historical Society

717094f-a.text:
Broadwav (right, center) south from about Fulton Street as viewed from (according to the writer) either the Woolworth or the Americar Telegraph ard Telephone Building, to show an early view of the downtown financial area. Prominent in the center are the Singer, Cunard, Whitehall and Standard Oil Buildings. In the left foreground is the rectangular Federal Reserve Bank Bldg. Beyond these structures appears Governors Island lying in the upper bay between the Brooklyn (left) and Jersey (right) shores. In the distance, vaguely perceived is the Staten Island outline.
About 192O
Brown Bros.

717093f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Fulton Street, showing prominently the Singer and the Equitable Buildings on opposite sides of this thoroughfare. The edifice shown on the right is the 26-story American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Building, No. 207-195 Broadway, and occupying the block front from Fulton to Dey Streets.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

719963f-a.text:
Fulton Street, north side, west from but not including Broadway, to and including Church Street. The view shows the rear of the Vestry Office of Trinity Church, fronting on Church Street, and at the western extremity of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel Cemetery.
May 19, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

717112f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Fulton to Vesey Streets, showing St. Pauls Chapel surrounded by its churchyard. At the rear of the latter (facing on Church Street) appears a unit of the Trinity Church Offices.
About 1930
Ewing Galloway

717115f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Fulton to Vesey Streets. The above is the location of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel and where an unknown (to the writer) function is taking place. The flower strewn table is at the rear of the church and to the foot of the tablet commemorating the bravery of General Richard Montgomery. Fulton Street is on the left. View No. 2 is in the opposite direction and silhouettes the reverend bagpiper against the Astor Building.
About 1932
Views 1 and 2

717115f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, from Fulton to Vesey Streets. The above is the location of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel and where an unknown (to the writer) function is taking place. The flower strewn table is at the rear of the church and to the foot of the tablet commemorating the bravery of General Richard Montgomery. Fulton Street is on the left. View No. 2 is in the opposite direction and silhouettes the reverend bagpiper against the Astor Building.

Views 1 and 2

719962f-a.text:
Fulton Street, north side, west from but not including Broadway, to and including Church Street. The view shows a portion of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel and grounds, the Sixth Ave., Elevated on Church Street, and the New York Telephone Building (West Street), are in the background.
June 4, 1933.
P.L. Sperr.

717116f.text:
Broadway, west side, between Fulton and Vesey Streets, showing a view of stones inside of St. Pauls Churchyard. This, a set of 3 views shows in No. 1, the Rhinelander plot; No. 2, the tombstones of Captain James
Lawrence; No. 3 the "United" graves.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

717100f.text:
Broadway and Fulton Street.
St. Paul's Church.
n.d.

717108f-b.text:
St. Pauls P.E. Chapel, Broadway.west side, between Fulton and Vesey Streets. A set of 3 views eastward on Fulton Street, showing the Chapel and grounds as seen from the rear. The 7-story white structure appearing on the left is the Astor Building, at the N.W . corner of Broadway and Vesey Street. Those on the right are Nos. 212, 6-story United Building, at the N.E. corner of Fulton Street and Broadway; No. 214, 7-story National Park Bank and No. 220-222, the 25-story St. Paul Building. All of the latter are on the east side of Broadway, north from Fulton to Ann Streets.
May 1923.
View No. 2:-May 1925.
View No. 3:eJuly 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(4)
The same as seen eastward on Vesey Street; the north side of the dhurch Yard. On the right appears a portion of the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Building, at the S.W. corner of Broadway and Fulton
Street.
May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

717109f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, between Fulton (left) and Vesey (center) Streets as seen southwestward on Park Row, and showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and grounds occupying that block,west to Church Street. Partially shown on the right is the Astor Building, at the N.W . corner of Broadway and Vesey Street. This is a set of 3 views, No. 1 and 2 being in the same direction while No. 3 is viewed eastward on Vesey Street (church yards northern boundary) from Church Street to Broadway. Nos. 2 and 3 show
the Chapel and spire under renovations.
October 1925.
Views 2 & 3:eJuly 17, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

717113f-b.text:
Broadway, (center, main entrance thereon) west side, between Fulton (right) and Vesey (left) Streets, showing St. Pauls Chapel with its surrounding Grave Yard that extends to Church Street (right foreground); this view being eastward from the latter point. Buildings across the background are on the east side of Broadway between Ann (left) and Fulton Streets, prominent of which is the 25-story St. Paul Building.
No. 220-222 Broadway.
June 4, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same from a slightly different angle. The twin towered structure] shown on the left is the 32-story Park Row Building. No. 13-21
Park Row.

719961f-b.text:
(1)
Fulton Street, north side, east from and including Broadway, to, but not including NasSau Street. Also shown is Broadway, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Fulton Stret. St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church is on the extreme left.
About 1904.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
A portion of the same in a westward direction and showing the Chapel and Grounds with the Trinity Vestry Buildings at their rear (Church Street). On the right appears a portion of the Knox Building, later called the United Building, which bears Nos. 212 Broadway and 165 Fulton Street.
June 3, 1904.
Brown Brothers.
